we know we mostly were talking about the design of objects and artifacts uh maybe you know if you were

uh teaching Institute where we're teaching design thinking to everyone on campus and and literally to people all

um things like that um creating not only
um obese children but children um who when they grow up are at risk of diabetes and other uh illnesses and

thinking has really been um fundamental in moving people people to
um uh using design in their organizations in very different ways so people think about design in the

is much more of a way to find new problems find and frame problems in a
creative way so that the solutions you generate are really new um new
strategies new systems new paradigms and they're generally in between domains are
very multidisciplinary in their nature so I mean the the term Paradigm
paradigm shift and it's a new paradigm is pretty overused and I want to make
sure we understand what we're talking about when we use the term Paradigm in a design thinking context and this is a
fantastic slide um by um uh Richard Pascal and um
and his colleagues that were looking at Paradigm shifts and for uh the purpose
of illustration they used the high jump as a methodology um today people are jumping
you know somewhere between uh 90 95 98 Ines in height which I just find
astonishing um you know I'm I'm 61 and these people are jumping uh over my head
by a couple of feet um but in the in the early part of the um of the 20th century
in the 1900s uh the Olympic records were in the 70 in 70 mid 70inch range and people use
what was called the scissor kick they literally jumped straight up with their butt going over the bar and their legs
scissoring to um provide some lift and leverage um they were also landing on
straw mats which were rather hard couple technology changes the mats got a little
softer and people um invented the western roll which is a means of sort of
rolling your body over the bar by lifting your up up outside leg up high
lifting your body over and then rolling over the bar and you can see that what happened is the Western Ro just was a
whole new paradigm for high jumping and the heights you went up um sort of uh
significantly in that period Then Came the straddle kick the straddle kick was a big innovation a huge um burst in
Heights went from you know the mid 80s from the low 80s to the mid 80s in inches um also uh improved mats at this
point um added some extra technology to the game and people could land um in a
more precarious position and finally there was a guy named dick Fosbury who
um had not been a particularly successful uh high jumper in college uh
but he invented a method of going over the bar head first and landing on his neck this of course would have been
impossible without the technology of foam mats and other things that were that were then allowed to increase the
safety uh of the high jump in international competition but The Fosbury Flop resulted in a huge U burst
of um new records and you know propelling people well into the 90in category so you can see what happened at
each of these different way completely different ways of approaching the kinematics of lifting your body over a
high bar um and recognizing that in each case some new technology enabled a new
approach you see what we're talking about when we talk about a paradigm shift and the paradigm shift from design
as a sort of um methodology to increase the uh appeal of products or services to
design thinking which is a methodology of finding new problems and approaching them in a strategic manner creates a
completely new paradigm and it shifts the way in which organizations can
perform and we think of it primarily in terms of
culture so when you approach uh designing an organization from scratch
and we um we work with lots of lots of startups here in Silicon Valley and a lot of startups that come off the Stanford campus um we talk talk about
creating a design culture or a design thinking culture um and culture is
simply the set of rules that that Define people's behavior um when they you know enter a
workplace or when they live in you know Western Society um culture is this
invisible set of guidelines that tell us how we should act and literally how we
should think when we approach um an organization so if you're starting a a
company from scratch creating a design culture while while challenging um is uh
very doable when you're in an existing organization we'll talk about that in a second we've had a couple of um webinars
on transformation of organizations and teams but let's just talk for the moment
about creating a culture in a new organization what kind of a culture do you want to create well in design we
start with this notion of creative confidence uh David Kelly who's one of the senior professors here at Stanford
also uh started a company called Ido which is probably the world's uh most famous International um design and
Innovation firm um he's also the founder of the D school he just gave a Ted Talk on this subject because what we're
finding with the D school is we're bringing uh students and graduate students from all of the seven schools
at the University School of Medicine School of Law School of Business School of Education and there they have no
previous design experience and we run them through what we call a boot camp and then they take a dchool class
typically on a subject of their choice um we're doing a class where we're designing products in af in Africa for
you know the disad disadvantage of the developing World we're doing uh other you know products um uh where we're
classes where we're designing designing services or interventions um in other parts of uh
the country for various problems like the childhood AB problem so they take these classes and they leave and they
almost uh every single student reports some kind of a transformation and we
asked them what happened they say something to the effect of I got my
confidence back that I'm a creative person or I got my creativity back and
it's one of these interesting things where um I think we we probably all felt we were more creative when we were kids
when we were young and we didn't know that there were rules and we weren't embarrassed about being goofy we we had
a sort of creative confidence and then unfortunately through the process process of being educated in our Western
Society we lost our ability to access this kind of thinking and one of the
most important things you do in the design thinking culture is create an environment where people's creativity is
not only nurtured it's required it's demanded of people to give a okay
solution or a pretty good solution is not enough you need to give a creative solution so I was at Apple for seven
years um not actually not while Steve Jobs was there I joined just before just
after he was um fired by the board and I left just before he returned so I was called that time I was at Apple between
jobs but um the uh the thing about Apple even when Steve wasn't there and
certainly when he was if you've read the autobiography that um uh or the biography that wter isacson wrote Steve
demanded insanely great products and insanely great is the same sort of principle we use use at the D school
it's got to be creative it's got to be incredible it has to be delightful it has to be something when you see it it
truly does knock your socks off and when you ask people to do that kind of work and you give them the tools to access
their creative creativity they develop a new sense of themselves so the most important thing about this culture this
is a culture of creativity and the ability to feel like you can um exhibit
your best and most creative self is fact that it's demanded and supported when you go to
work the next thing is a culture of collaboration we call it
radical collaboration this is a you know these are pictures from the early version of the D school you can see

design thinking we really mean radical we mean bringing people in from the
field sales organization people from Finance people from you know a radical
collaboration isn't getting four different kinds of designers or Engineers together that's that's just
something you should do anyway for good project teams but radical collaboration is truly bringing people in from
different parts of the organization and also from your your customer base co-creation
um through um what we we start with what we call empathy and need finding Cod Creation with your customers is
essential part of this process so if you have a place that's naturally creative
that nurtures and fosters interaction between uh different kinds of people people who normally don't interact
together and you combine that with what we consider is the most important thing a culture of empathy empathy for your
customers empathy for the needs you're trying to solve empathy for the big question why do we matter what is our
mission in the world and who are we trying to impact we start with uh empathy in all of our projects briefs we
assume we don't know what we are trying to solve although we might have a you might say well it's childhood obesity
it's a problem we want to work on it we don't understand how to intervene and we start by interviewing kids we start by
interviewing parents and then we interview doctors and other experts but primarily we go directly to the source
of the problem because what we find is in almost every single case the
definition of the problem is incorrect I've been doing um professional design Consulting for about 25 years and I can
tell you that in 25 years not a single client has come in the front door of my consulting firm um which is called design to matter
by the way um they never they've never come in with the right problem the problem is always framed too narrowly um
and it's framed in the case of a symptom not a root cause and so empathy work
need finding the cultural anthropology the ethnography that we do is critical to creating this environment where um
design thinking thrives of course it's a culture of ideas um if you come to the D school or
you come to any of the design firms that use these processes in the outside world you will see walls and walls and walls
unfortunately full of poits it's a very non-ecological um method of of problem
solving we do use brainstorming we use uh biomimicry we used uh forced
morphologies or morphological analysis we use mind mapping we use all sorts of techniques to create a huge huge number
of ideas for the solutions that we're solutions for the ideas that we're trying to solve um we really think that
um the evidence is clear and we can point you to many many studies that if you choose from a large number of ideas
you will choose better and so we are idea junkies uh in this culture and then
we believe in a sort of bias to action you can't have smart people in a room thinking about Solutions but you can um
Build Your Way Forward you can make things so we're a a a design thinking
culture a culture to D school or a culture in a organization that you're trying to transform should fundamentally
be a culture of prototyping you should you should be building um very low resolution very
poorly made um examples of possible solutions to the problem you're working
on and these are not designed to be in fact Solutions they're just designed to be things to provoke questions because
the questions go back out into the uh empathy work and that circular relationship between uh trying to
understand and frame the need prototyping partial Solutions asking people if these are the things that they were thinking that they wanted and going
back and back and back through that cycle uh of iteration is one that um really really I think helps people
understand what it is that they're trying to do in the end so if you have a culture that that
values ideas and collaboration that starts with a you know kind of a deep
understanding of human needs and then assuming that it doesn't know anything builds its way forward you have created
what we consider to be the most important thing which is a culture of design thinking and there's a a great um
great quote that I like to um use a lot this is from Alan Mele who's the CEO of Ford I think he's just about to retire

Alan o was in um was walking through one of the engineering buildings and one of the young Engineers had put this sign up
uh just printed it out and put it up in the um in the break room and the sign said culture eats process for lunch and

be a culture that cares more about you know um Counting beans and managing
process Mele really took that to heart and he changed the way he was organizing
um the company and the way he managed it because he realized that culture this invisible set of rules of what we do and

important thing for him to manage the process would take care of itself that
there were lots of smart people who could make sure that processes were managed well and that tollgates were followed but that if nobody cared about
the most important thing the thing that really mattered cars making cars that
connected with Ford fires making cars that brought back that you know kind of
excitement of the Ford Mustang or um really you know made um the con a deep
connection with people so people would say wow if Ford went out of business that would really matter to me right so
he changed the way he was managing uh the organization and um it became a much
healthier much more um passionate car culture um they do radical collaboration
they've broken down a lot of the silos between design engineering styling um the You Know Field sales they've

the or organization and I love this quote uh this was uh you know something that was
um told by Allan andak he did here at Stanford um and uh uh I love the quote
because I think it really captures what we're trying to do we're not saying when we say you know switch to a design

culture um and in fact you know the we we are not the strong proponents of any

I've left that process diagram out of this presentation on purpose because I really want to focus more on a culture
or a mind mindset if you were creating a brand new company or trying to transform your own you got to ask yourself what is

and why does it matter um and then you have to try to build these processes um
around that culture so that if you have a design culture that values ideas and creativity uh it can flourish now I mean

does not it does not take it does not happen um we've looked at this problem
and we've identified at least three significant places where these types of
um Transformations get blocked um the first one is um is a very
personal one um it's a conceptual block conceptual blocks um and some of this uh
language comes from a guy named James Adams who wrote a book called um conceptual blockbusting a guide to
better ideas uh Professor Adams uh is Professor Amer is here at Stanford one of the guys who began the design um
thinking and design um division here at Stanford um back in the 70s he
identified these conceptual blocks and they represent primarily personal challenges in the organization
conceptual blocks impact the universe of perceived actions um they your your own
blocks uh impact what you believe is possible and the blocks come in four
versions intellectual perceptual emotional and cultural but um in in
organizations they're primary organizational culture culture that make you believe that certain things are not
possible they cannot happen um and because of those blocks um the diffusion
of design thinking you know can often fail then there's semantic blocks or
semantic gaps this is more of an organizational challenge um people use
different words to mean the same thing people use the same words to mean different things very small differences
matter when it count ing talks about um numbers and when engineering talks about
numbers they really are not talking about the same subject although the words might seem to be the same um and
and because uh design thinking requires these highly diverse radical
collaboration teams these um teams are are very subject it's misunderstanding
each other and not not being able to function because they simply don't share
common language or even common outcomes um it's it's often funny when
you talk to engineers and they say I don't know what the marketing guys do they just make PowerPoint slides and the marketing people say I

engineer views their output to be an object and and a um a person in marketing often views their their uh
work product their output to be Concepts embodied inside of a very well
structured presentation so semantic gaps can often trip up organizations as they move into
multi-disciplinary work radical collaboration um and they discover that people uh neither understand nor value
the same things from different parts of the organization and then finally there's just social barriers um and eily
described as the you know like Engineers eat Engineers with Engineers eat lunch with Engineers marketing people eat
lunch with marketing people Finance people eat lunch by themselves um it's it's just not common in organizations
for people to socialize across the aisle there's interesting just to diverge

going wrong in Washington and it used to be that in Washington DC Senators when they were elected moved to Washington
lived in Washington and had you know social interactions with other Congress and senator congressman and senators
from across the aisle they would you know play golf together they would go to dinner together their families knew each other so even though they were polit
from different political parties there was some kind of social lubrication that allowed an informal communication to
occur and there was much less gridlock nowadays because of the demands of um
running for political office and raising money no one actually lives in Washington they fly in have a temporary

this social um um informal socialization is occurring it's the same thing is true
in companies it's a it's a challenge of networks you don't have any information outside the network of people that you
work with and typically those networks um are functionally based but when you
think about the kinds of projects and challenges you face in most organization functional Solutions are inadequate you
need system solel Solutions so there's a lot of big there's a lot of big issues um when it
comes to creating these cultures of innovation and cultures of design thinking but there are solutions to each
of these so let's let's kind of Zoom back again out to what so what were the
big questions we were asking um most organizations spend all
of their time looking at how to capture the value of the goods and services that
they provide and I'm sure many of you have been through this um these processes Six
Sigma is very popular was very popular you know in the early part of the 2000s
um great way of capturing more value and making sure that you get rid of variation so that all the products and
services are the same or before Six Sigma was total quality management and now everybody's talking about lean
startups and lean development or Agile development these are all new systems
but when you really break them all down and they're all very valuable of course they all approach the problem with slightly different different uh points
of view they really break down into things that are assuming you have a
product or a service that is valued by a customer how can you extract more and
more and more value from that product or service but the real question is how much time are you spending on value
creation design thinking is about this side of the equation much more so than it's about value capture now you can
capture more value when you tie your products more specifically to the need needs and emotions of your customers but
fundamentally designed thinking is a is a methodology for looking at the value
creation side of the equation and in value creation you know you look towards and I think one of the reasons
everybody's starting to talk about design is they're looking at companies like apple and Harley and BMW and others
who are winning by Design and they're saying where's that coming from where are they getting all these good design
ideas well of course partly they're getting them from their designers design is the one
part of an organization just traditional design making you know excellent products uh beautiful and and better um
that's still one part of the organization whose sole focus is the organic growth of the company by
providing new and different uh products in the product line you know that the
company is interested in and when you think about it it's it's surprisingly monotonic I was seven years at Apple I
never designed a Teddy Barrett Apple I never designed a toaster I never designed an automobile
despite the fact that everybody seems to think they're designing a TV they're we're not they never designed a TV they
just do one thing they design computers big ones small ones handheld ones ones that go in your pockets um it's a very
very simple business model but it has a a strong core based in design and so the
value creation side you got to ask yourself how much of your day how much of your working day working week working
month J take out your you're you know if you're a consultant take out your time sheet if you're somebody who just likes
the journal or just has a complicated calendar go look over your calendar and tell me how much time did you spend in
the value capture side of your business and how much time did you spend on the value creation and my guess is you're
going to discover that you spend not nearly enough time thinking about the big question because value
creation is how you um approach the problem of are we going to do we matter
what what is the purpose of this business how does this business function
to Delight our customers in a way that gives us just a significant strategic Advantage which is
sustainable and there's a whole sustainable strategic Advantage Michael Porter Riff on design thinking which I
think you know we could say for a different um a different talk but but when you look at organizations and for
instance Apple just reported its earnings um last week you know 150% more
um iPad sold than the previous quarter almost double their net profit
um it's a juggernaut at this point and it can't be stopped because no one else was asking the questions how do we

the thing we've already made right and so they they they lost connection with the reason that they would matter
so then the other the other you know so the other dialogue or the other Duality is um you know are you doing the right
are you doing things right are you doing things right in your organization it's kind of another version of value capture but but really this is the process
question do we have a good process are we doing things right are we hitting our tool gates are we managing our process
does everybody know where they are in the process so that we're a coordinated organization and those are all really
really important questions but bigger than those questions is the questions are you doing the right thing doing
things right is about execution doing the right thing that's really about Reed that's
the redefining and reframing the problem that you're
working on in design we use the empathy step to create what we call a point of view the point of view is not in science
we have a hypothesis and then we go out and we get data and we prove the hypothesis right or wrong in design we
have a thing we call a point of view which we Define as a need plus a user plus an Insight so I I've talked to my
users and I understand who they are what what is this when I talk about a market a market is just a bunch of people who buy the same stuff and talk to each
other who are they what do they love why what do they care why do they buy this and not something else what don't they
buy what what would they want in addition to what we already offer if I understand the people and their needs
and I have an Insight oh maybe this part of you know the needs really um is
unserved yet or maybe there's a latent need under the thing they tell me maybe there's something that's latent if I'm
doing that kind of work I'm really working on doing the right thing I'm I'm
making sure that I'm um getting on I'm getting the ball to go down the right
side of the mountain because once I start the ball all the doing things right processes you know take over and
once that bul is going down the hill anyway it's going to just keep going I mean nobody's going to stop it so I want to make sure I let the ball go on the
right side of the hill and it's a 360 problem because I can let it go on the
left or the right or in the middle or the the back or anywhere in between and boy that is the most important question
you should be wrestling with not are we ready for the you know next Tollgate
review the question at every point along the way should be have we redefined the problem problem
Are we heading for a blue ocean have we framed it in a way that's not about the
symptoms but it's truly about a root cause and are we getting the ball on the right side of the mountain because once
